entries.text: Do you eat Javascript for lunch? Are you familiar with Web Servers such as IIS and Apache? Do you dig Perl the most? Then join Striata! We will make best use of your talent, while ensuring that you grow and learn in an environment that boasts some of the best developers in the industry. Apply now!
entries.title: Looking for Perl Gurus to work in exciting development environment

entries.author: miguel_prz
entries.text: Miguel Prz (NICEPERL)'s regular lists: Great modules released last week; MetaCPAN weekly report; StackOverflow Perl report.
entries.title: NICEPERL's lists

entries.author: ricardo_signes
entries.text: Rik has released a module (RTF::VimColor) and associated script (synrtf which will take some code and produce an RTF file which has syntax highlighting on the code.
entries.title: Syntax highlighting as RTF

entries.author: yanick_champoux
entries.text: Yanick presents File::Serialize which will (de)serialise YAML, JSON and TOML, using the 'right' module behind the scenes, so you don't have to remember which is the right module to use these days.
entries.title: Sometimes, It's the Little Things

entries.author: lee_johnson
entries.text: Lee describes a change that he's made to CGI which simplifies the code and will mean CGI now gets correct test coverage results. It's currently a developer release, so please test it if you use CGI.
entries.title: Removing AUTOLOAD from CGI.pm

entries.author: aristotle_pagaltzis
entries.text: Aristotle presents a small perl script which illustrates a way that the unwary, and those new to Perl, can be surprised when playing around with subroutine arguments.
entries.title: Today's bit of black perl

entries.text: Ivan presents an easy-to-install monitoring system he's created called curry, which is built on Docker and Dancer.
entries.title: Using Perl Dancer and Docker to create simple monitoring system

entries.text: You often read about the need to call make_immutable on your Moose classes, but do you know what the impact can be if you don't? kd benchmarked one of his webs after before and after, and found that adding make_immutable made it 5 times faster.
entries.title: Always make immutable (unless you have a good reason not to)

entries.author: e_choroba
entries.text: For his February assignment, E decided to look into his dist's CPAN Testers failures. He describes his approach and how it led in his pull request. The comments on his post point out some other tools that can help this sort of investigation.
entries.title: Analysing CPAN Testers' Reports

entries.author: philippe_bruhat
entries.text: You may think of him as "BooK", or "the guy in the pink shirt". Philippe has added some new pages onto cpan.io which show leaderboards for all years, such as this one.
entries.title: CPAN.io, yearly boards and gamification

entries.author: yanick_champoux
entries.text: Yanick introduces the inversion of control concept, and presents how you can do it with Bread::Board. Obviously Canada has multiple definitions for the word 'gentle'.
entries.title: A Gentle Introduction to Bread::Board

entries.author: frew_schmidt
entries.text: Frew shows how his thoughts on handling configuration has evolved via various technologies, to his latest approach.
entries.title: Configuration Station

entries.author: david_bradford
entries.text: David ask what sources of tech news do the rest of you (us) follow, which he might find of interest. He means aside from Perl Weekly, of course.
entries.title: How do you join the conversation?

entries.author: billy_vierra
entries.text: Billy has created a Chrome extension that will automatically redirect you from search.cpan.org to MetaCPAN.
entries.title: Automatic chrome redirect from SCO to MetaCPAN

entries.author: neil_bowers
entries.text: There are several hundred people taking part in the pull request challenge who want to fix your bugs. All you need to do is put your distribution on github, and make sure the repo is listed in the metadata.
entries.title: CPAN dists not on github

entries.author: curtis_ovid_poe
entries.text: Curtis shows how Perl 6's gradual typing can prevent certain types of bugs in your code. He throws some other Perl 6 titbits in as well.
entries.title: Avoid a Common Software Bug By Using Perl 6

entries.author: moritz_lenz
entries.text: Moritz presents the IRC bot camelia, which will run Perl 6 code snippets seen in the #perl6 IRC channel, and give feedback on them. I have to admit that my first thought was wondering what naughtiness might be possible, but it's pretty cool!
entries.title: Profiling Perl 6 code on IRC

entries.author: david_golden
entries.text: David lays out his current thinking on Perl 6. TL;DR: likes some bits, but thinks it seems large / complex and under-documented at the moment.
entries.title: Thoughts on getting Perl 6 for Christmas

entries.text: The weekly Perl 6 update: performance improvements; the 'long' type, and stricter laxness, among other things.
entries.title: I like trains! Fast trains, that is ...

entries.author: makoto_nozaki
entries.text: Nozaki-san has proposed a change to TPF rules for grants, aimed at defining a deadline for all grant applications, beyond which projects would be deemed to have failed. If you have an opinion, please add a comment.
entries.title: RFC: Limiting grant duration

entries.author: karen_pauley
entries.text: Karen posted Dave Mitchell's latest report for his TPF grant to support work on the Perl 5 core.
entries.title: Maintaining the Perl 5 Core: Report, Month 16

entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.text: Some explanation about the CPAN Testers and about cpXXXan.
entries.title: CPAN for older versions of Perl

entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.text: Files generated by the Perl toolchain, by the editor, an even by the operating system should usually be excluded from version control system. Here is a list of what should be excluded and how to to that.
entries.title: Don't keep generated files in version control

entries.author: dan_wright
entries.text: Dan described all the different ways you can keep up-to-date on news related to YAPC::NA.
entries.title: Looking for YAPC::NA News?

header: We're definitely getting more blog posts about Perl 6 since FOSDEM. I wonder if that's going to continue for the rest of the year, or if it's still the after-effect from FOSDEM...
More than anything, participants in the Pull Request challenge seem to want to fix bugs. Put your buggy dists on github! :-)
subject: The FOSDEM after-effect
